introText: You can use the preliminary test to see how well you know the basic concepts and requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation. You will receive a compiled report of your answers after the test.

questions.question: If your company only stores the personal data of people representing other companies, it does not have to worry about the requirements of the GDPR.

choices.selectedText: Incorrect – The data of persons who represent companies is also personal data and must be processed according to the requirements of the GDPR. You should also take remember that if a company has even a single employee, it is probably functioning as a controller with regard to the employee's personal data.

A person can also be identified directly based on information such as their name, personal identity code or some other characteristic feature.

questions.question: The General Data Protection Regulation discusses the processing of personal data at length. What does processing mean?

choices.option: Processing only refers to the active use of data. Merely storing data does not constitute processing
choices.selectedText: Incorrect – All operations involving personal data, from collection to erasure, constitute processing. Processing includes activities such as the collection, storage, use, transfer and disclosure of personal data.

questions.question: If the information on the company's customers, such as addresses and telephone numbers, are only saved in a phone, the General Data Protection Regulation does not apply to it.

choices.selectedText: Incorrect – If the personal data has been collected for the company's purposes, the GDPR applies to it regardless of the medium or device used for processing. Therefore, the requirements of the GDPR also apply to personal data processed on a phone. For example, you are required to protect the personal data appropriately, update it regularly and erase it when the storage time expires. The GDPR does not apply to data processed for private purposes, such as the data of your friends and family members.

questions.question: What does it mean if the processing of personal data is based on the company's legitimate interest?

choices.option: In certain situations, the company can, for example, market its services to its customers without their separate consent
choices.selectedText: Correct – In certain situations, the processing of personal data can be justified by the legitimate interest of the controller or a third party. Processing can be in the controller's legitimate interest if there is a significant relationship between the controller and data subject. This is the case if the data subject is the controller's customer, for example. If the controller intends to use legitimate interest as a basis for processing, it must first conduct a balance test to carefully assess whether legitimate interest can be used as a basis for the processing.
choices.selectedActions: More information on the bases for processing: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/when-is-the-processing-of-personal-data-permitted and on legitimate interest as a basis for processing: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/controller-s-legitimate-interests

questions.question: Flower Ltd sells its products through an online shop, where it also stores its customer information, such as names and addresses. Computer Ltd is responsible for the technical maintenance of the online shop. From the perspective of data protection, the role of Computer Ltd is:

choices.selectedText: Incorrect – Computer Ltd is a processor. Computer Ltd is only responsible for the technical maintenance of Flower Ltd's online shop. Processors are parties, such as service providers, that process data according to the controller's instructions and for purposes specified by the controller. Flower Ltd, on the other hand, is a controller, i.e. a party that decides what personal data is collected and how it is used. As the controller, Flower Ltd has the primary responsibility for the processing of personal data.

questions.question: The General Data Protection Regulation provides for ”special categories of personal data”, which include, among others, health data and data indicating an individual's political opinion or sexual orientation. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.option: Companies may not process such data under any circumstances.
choices.selectedText: Incorrect – The processing of special categories of personal data is generally prohibited, but can be permitted if there is an exceptional basis for the processing, such as the data subject's explicit consent for the processing of such data. Special categories of personal data consist of racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, health data, sexual orientation or sex life, as well as genetic or biometric data used to identify individuals.

questions.question: You find out that an outsider has acquired your username and password or those of a colleague, granting access to your email client. What should you do?

choices.option: It is enough to ensure that the leaked password is changed.
choices.selectedText: Incorrect – If a username and password are disclosed to third parties, it is highly probable that they can be used to access the company's personal data. In other words, personal data may have been leaked to unauthorised parties, so just changing your password will not suffice. The company must follow the GDPR's requirements for dealing with personal data breaches. In the GDPR, a personal data breach is defined as an incident that results in the destruction, loss, alteration or unauthorised disclosure of personal data, or that grants a party not authorised to process the data access to personal data.

questions.question: The General Data Protection Regulation prohibits the transfer of personal data out of the EU/EEA.

choices.selectedText: Incorrect – The GDPR does not prohibit or prevent the transfer of data outside the EU/EEA. However, transferring data outside the EU/EEA requires an appropriate basis for the transfer in addition to compliance with the other provisions of data protection legislation.
